awd_titl_txt: Single Nanoparticle SPR Imaging Measurements of Bioaffinity Uptake and Release in Polymer and DNA-Cross-linked Nanoparticles
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Corn at the University of California, Irvine, is developing and applying new optical techniques that can detect, characterize and monitor in real time the size and composition of single polymer nanoparticles. Understanding how porous polymer nanoparticles uptake, transport, and then release biologically active molecules such as nucleic acids and proteins are fundamentally important and interesting. Professor Corn develops better chemical methods to improve the uniformity, reliability, and stability of characterization of these nanoparticles. Professor Corn's research outcome could lead to technological advances in the fields of sensor development, drug delivery, and disease diagnostics. Professor Corn's project provides participating students with research experience in a diverse set of disciplines: polymer materials and characterization, nanomaterials, laser microscopy, biosensors and biotechnology. Development of young scientists with such a wide range of skills is essential for both industry and academia to successfully address future multi-disciplinary technological challenges. In addition to research, this grant supports education and outreach programs that attract high school students from underfunded schools and middle school female students interested in science to the STEM fields.

Single nanoparticle near-infrared surface plasmon resonance imaging (SPRI) microscopy is developed as a novel refractive index-based method to quantify the bioaffinity uptake and release of various biomolecules into individual porous polymeric nanoparticles. SPRI is an established refractive index-based technique for monitoring molecular and nanoparticle adsorption onto gold thin films.  The application of SPRI microscopy is expanded here to single nanoparticle measurements that can monitor the uptake and release of biomolecules (both single nanoparticle averages and distribution measurements) in real time by measuring changes in the single nanoparticle refractive index that occur due to changes in composition. A variety of modified N-isopropylacrylamide (NIPAm) hydrogel nanoparticles that can uptake and release different proteins, lectins, nucleic acids, peptides, and pharmaceuticals are synthesized and studied.  Three specific research efforts include: (i) the synthesis and characterization of NIPAm hydrogel nanoparticles that incorporate click chemistry sites to attach sugars, peptides, or DNA for the bioaffinity uptake and release of therapeutics, proteins, and RNA, (ii) the synthesis and characterization of DNA-cross-linked NIPAm (N-isopropylacrylamide)hydrogel nanoparticles that incorporate DNA aptamers and DNAzymes, and (iii) single-nanoparticle measurements of pH and temperature-induced morphological changes in NIPAm hydrogel nanoparticles that release various cargo (e.g., peptides, enzymes, DNA, and gold nanoparticles).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Final Outcomes Report: January 2022

NSF Award CHE-1807317

Single Nanoparticle SPR Imaging Measurements of Bioaffinity Uptake and Release in Polymer and DNA-Cross-linked Nanoparticles

Period: 7/1/19 - 12/31/21

PI: Robert M. Corn

 

The need for the accurate detection of small amounts of proteins and nucleic acids in saliva, blood and urine has been thrust into the public spotlight with the COVID-19 pandemic.  Our NSF award has centered on the development and characterization of new methods that use single nanoparticles for the detection of proteins and nucleic acids at extremely low concentrations (thousands of molecules in a microliter).  Target molecules (proteins, RNA, DNA, antibodies) are detected when attached to either polymeric, metal (gold or silver) or magnetic (ferrite) nanoparticles that contain protein or nucleic acid binding sites (bioprobe molecules); this process is called bioaffinity uptake or adsorption.  The single nanoparticles are detected with either fluorescence or surface plasmon resonance imaging (SPRI) microscopy. SPRI microscopy is particularly useful in the quantification of the bioaffinity uptake and release of biomolecules in non-fluorescent polymeric nanoparticles. The research undertaken in this grant can be divided into three major areas:

 

(i) The fabrication of novel nanoparticles for bioaffinity applications. Included in this area are the synthesis of polyamide-based nanoparticles that incorporate proteins and DNA inside the nanoparticle, the synthesis and characterization of DNA-silver and RNA-silver fluorescent nanoclusters that can be incorporated into bioaffinity nanoparticles for marking and detection, the electrochemical generation of silver nanoparticles in microfluidic channels, and the synthesis and characterization of single crystal ferrite magnetic nanoparticles for the facile separation and purification of bioaffinity nanoparticles.

 

(ii) The development of SPRI microscopy to detect and quantify single polymer and metal nanoparticles. In SPRI, adsorbed single nanoparticles appear as point diffraction patterns in the microscope images; we showed that the intensity of these diffraction patterns can used to detect the presence of target biomolecules in polymer nanoparticles.  SPRI microscopy diffraction patterns from gold nanorods and silver nanoplates were found to exhibit a wide range of unusual optical diffraction patterns that could be analyzed by the development of new scattering theory calculations that included an anisotropic resonant scattering component.

 

(iii) The development of new microfluidic methods for the separation and detection of bioaffinity nanoparticles. In this area we expanded the use of more complex microfluidic channel geometries with fluorescence and SPRI microscopy. Microfluidic mazes and cross channel geometries were fabricated to sort objects based on size, fluorescent lifetime and bioaffinity surface interactions. Initial experiments on maze solving and particle sorting that utilized passive pressure gradient flow of polymer microparticles and electrogenerated fluorescent molecules in microchannel networks were performed.

 

All of the projects in these three major areas of this grant helped enhance our fundamental understanding of how to create, manipulate and utilize bioaffinity nanoparticles for the detection of biomarkers for cancer, viral infections and other diseases. Expansion of this knowledge base directly impacts and benefits health care both locally and globally in the crucial areas of disease detection and management as well as in the future development of novel directed therapeutic drug delivery systems.
